column2: When teachers need to communicate with parents, they often send letters home with their students. Jane's eleven-year-old son brought this letter home with him from school.

column3: I am so excited to be working with your brilliant children this year! For our social studies lessons, we will be learning about world geography. Throughout the year, we will study different countries from each continent. Next semester, I will assign each student a specific country for a final project. I will send another letter about that project later on.

For now, I actually need to enlist your help! Each time we study a new continent or region, I want to invite a guest presenter to come in. This will make the lessons more entertaining and fun for the students. I am looking for presenters who are from or have lived in a foreign country. If you or someone you know has experience with one of the following regions and can do a presentation, please contact me!
Northern Africa and the Middle East

I am including a map of the countries in each region, but please let me know if you have any questions! The presentations will last for about an hour. You can discuss the history, the culture, the food, and your own experiences there. Please bring souvenirs or other objects to enrich your lesson if possible. We would love to try some typical food from each region as well!
Thank you in advance for your help! Working with you will make our class more exciting!

In your opinion, what is the most important thing on the list to find first in a new area? How about the second and third most important? Why?

Maria Teresa doesn’t know anyone in her new area. She left a note on her neighbor’s door to ask some questions. Two days later, her neighbor, Collette, came to Maria Teresa’s house. Maria Teresa wasn’t home, so Collette left her a note as well. You will see both notes.

column3: Hello! My daughter and I just moved in to the home across the street. We’ve been living in another country for several years, so we don’t have many friends in this area. We would love to meet your family. I noticed that your family left all together dressed in nice clothes on Sunday morning. I wondered if you were going to church. I would really like to attend a Christian church. I have many fond memories of attending my parents’ church as a young girl. I hope this isn’t intrusive, but where is your church? Also, what time does it start? I don’t have a phone number yet. Please stop by our home when you can.

Thank you for your note! We were out of town for two days, so we just found it. And now it looks like you aren’t home either! There’s no intrusion at all. We would be thrilled for you to come to church with us. Our meetings start at 11 a.m. every Sunday. The church is on Dixon Street. It’s actually a little tricky to locate. If you want, you can carpool with us. We have room in our car for two more people. In the meantime, we would like to invite you and your daughter to lunch on Saturday. I’ll leave you my phone number just in case you have a phone now. Can you come over around 12pm?

There are many religions in the world. What do you know about Christianity in America? Write one or two things you’ve heard about American religions such as Christianity or others.
Review these vocabulary words before looking at the email. They will help you understand the email.
<dd>written or spoken words that tell people about something.</dd>
<dd>Did you hear the announcement about today’s lunch?</dd>
<dd>a Christian book about the Jews and the life of Jesus Christ.</dd>
<dd>I try to read from the Bible every day.</dd>
Kenichi’s friend Rian saw an announcement on the university bulletin board. She thought that Kenichi might be interested in the announcement. She sent Kenichi this email.

Hi Kenichi!

I remember you asking me about getting to know Christianity better. I know you’re only here for a few semesters. However, I thought you might be interested in this. I saw an announcement on the wall this morning. It is about a Christian Bible study. Bible study is a popular activity for students here. The students get together and read about Jesus Christ in the Bible. Then they ask questions and talk about ideas. Usually there are treats at the end. This is a great time to make friends and learn more about Christianity. I’ve been to a Bible study in high school, but never in college. I really want to go. I think it would be fun if you came too! The announcement is attached.

Do not worry if you’re not interested. I just thought of you when I saw the announcement.

Rian

Do you like free cookies and ice cream?

If you answered “YES” to any of these questions, then Christian Bible Study is for you!

column2: Megan is a teenager who loves reading magazines. One day she reads a section in a magazine from her church about choosing friends. This is the section that she read.

column3: This month’s question comes from Joel. He lives in San Francisco, California.

“My parents say I should choose my friends with caution. But I know I shouldn’t judge others. So, I need some advice. I want to choose good friends. But at the same time, I don’t want to judge people too harshly. It’s tough to do that. What can I do?”

Our answer: Joel, we’ve got some tips for you. First of all, show respect and kindness to everybody. This isn’t the same as having a close friendship with everyone. In other words, be cautious. Follow your parents’ advice. Choose your close friends carefully. Your close friends will influence your life a lot. How can you know if a person will be a good friend? Ask yourself two questions. Do you make good choices in that person’s company? Will he or she always be there for you?
